import React, { Component } from 'react' import { CCard, CCardBody, CCardHeader, CCol, CRow, CTable, CTableBody, CTableDataCell, CTableHead, CTableHeaderCell, CTableRow, CSpinner, CFormLabel, CFormSelect, CFormInput } from '@coreui/react' import { API_URL } from '../../utils/constans' import axios from 'axios' // import ShowEntriesSearch from 'src/components/dataTables/ShowEntriesSearch' export default class list_menu extends Component { constructor(props) { super(props) this.state = { menus: [], currentPage: 1, totalData: 109, entriesToShow: 5, searchQuery: '', loading:true, } } componentDidMount() { const fetchData = async () => { axios .get(API_URL + `menu?limit=200`) .then((res) => { const menus = res.data this.setState({ menus }) // setLoading(false); }) .catch((error) => { console.log(error) }) } fetchData() } handleEntriesChange = (event) => { const entriesToShow = event.target.value this.setState(entriesToShow) } handleSearchChange = (event) => { const searchQuery = event.target.value this.setState(searchQuery) } render() { const { menus, entriesToShow, searchQuery, loading } = this.state return (
{loading ? ( ) : ( <> React Table Basic example

Using the most basic table CoreUI, here's how <CTable> -based tables look in CoreUI.

Show  No Menu Link Icon Status Action {menus && menus.map((item, index) => ( {index + 1} {item.name_menu} {item.link} {item.icon} {item.status} # ))} )}
) } }
